The fact of the matter is that the Second Amendment to the Constitution of the United States reads, "A well-regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the people, to keep and bear arms, shall not be infringed.["] No other portion of the Bill of Rights has this "shall not be infringed" clause, and that's significant.

 And it is significant that no other portion of the Bill of Rights is linked to a well regulated militia. No one has ever been able to explain to me why that phrase it there unless it specifically intends to link ownership of weapons to membership in the militia. Were this not true, if the writers of the 2nd Amentment actually meant that the it is the "unalienable right" of every individual to own a firearm, then only the part that begins with, "the right of the people..." is necessary.
 
 Perhaps it would help to understand what the militia is. It is provided for in the Constitution.
 
To provide for calling forth the militia to execute the laws of the union, suppress insurrections and repel invasions; 
 
 To provide for organizing, arming, and disciplining, the militia, and for governing such part of them as may be employed in the service of the United States, reserving to the states respectively, the appointment of the officers, and the authority of training the militia according to the discipline prescribed by Congress;

 That is from Article I that specifies the duties of Congress. So it would seem that the right to keep and bear arms is in the second meaning of that phrase, to serve as a soldier rather than just carry a weapon. So those who exercise their right are at the call of Congress, which body would then be responsible for arming, disciplining and governing them.
 
 And, of course, the President also has duties and powers that pertain to the militia.
 
The President shall be commander in chief of the Army and Navy of the United States, and of the militia of the several states, when called into the actual service of the United States;

 Perhaps the intent of the framers of the Constitution might be clearer with a little background, like the Virginia Constitution of 1776. Pay special attention to section 13.
 
That a well-regulated militia, composed of the body of the people, trained to arms, is the proper, natural, and safe defence of a free State; that standing armies, in time of peace, should be avoided, as dangerous to liberty; and that in all cases the military should be under strict subordination to, and governed by, the civil power.

 It is the right of the people (not of persons) that shall not be infringed, the right stated in the Virginia Constitution to train the body of the people in arms in order to defend the free state.
 
 This is clearly the intent of the 2nd Amendment.
 
 It is also interesting to note the list of grievences that concludes the Virginia Constitution. Many of them are quite similar, if not identical, to the Declaration.
 
 Another point that is always ignored by the "unalienable right" people is that the Bill of Rights were not written as "unalienable rights." The Bill of Rights applied to Congress. You can tell because the 1st Amendment begins with "Congress shall pass no law..." Since then there have been other Amendments that have expanded the original scope of the Constitution. The 14th Amendment guarantees all citizens the right to due process and equal protection of the laws. The Supreme Court has incorporated several Amendments against the states under the 14th Amendment. However, several have not. For example, the Constitutional ban against the quartering of troops in a private home has never been applied to the states in a court of law. The reason is simple. No state has ever tried to quarter troops. I'm pretty sure that if it should happen, the state would be found in violation of the Constitution.
 
 But neither has a 2nd Amendment case been applied to the States by the Supreme Court. It isn't as if there hasn't been a chance. The Supreme Court has just declined to hear such cases, thus allowing states and local governments to make laws that abridge the rights to keep and bear arms. In other words, most local gun control laws are probably Constitutional.
 
 If you want that changed, then violate the law and then make you case in such a way that the Supreme Court will listen and decide in your favor.
 
The Second Amendement means exactly today as it did when it was ratified in 1789, and only a constitutional amendment can change that!
